On the contrary, for our purposes it suffices to take $\mathbb{H}_{5}^{n}$ with its standard Euclidean scalar product. An orthonormal basis will be denoted by $e_{1},\ldots,e_{n}$ 
Definition 1.8.1 The Clifford algebra $\operatorname{Cl}(V)$ , also denoted $\operatorname{Cl}(n)$ , is the quotient of the tensor algebra $\bigoplus_{k\geq0}V\otimes\ldots\otimes V$ generated by $V$ by the two sided ideal generated by all elements of the form $v\otimes v+\|v\|^{2}$ for $v\in V$ 
Thus, the multiplication rule for the Clifford algebra $C1(V)$ is 
$$
v w+w v=-2\langle v,w\rangle
$$
In particular, in terms of our orthonormal basis $e_{1},\ldots,e_{n}$ ,wehave 
$$
{e_{i}}^{2}=-1\mathrm{and}e_{i}e_{j}=-e_{i}e_{j}\mathrm{for}i\ne j.
$$
From this, one easily sees that a basis of $\operatorname{Cl}(V)$ as a real vector space is given by 
$$
e_{0}:=1,\quad e_{\alpha}:=e_{\alpha_{1}}e_{\alpha_{2}}\dots e_{\alpha_{k}}
$$
with $\alpha=\{\alpha_{1},...,\alpha_{k}\}\subset\{1,...,n\}$ and $\alpha_{1}<\alpha_{2}\ldots<\alpha_{k}$ . For such an $\boldsymbol{C}$ ,we shall put $|\alpha|:=k$ in the sequel. Thus, as a vector space, $\operatorname{Cl}(V)$ is isomorphic to $\varLambda^{*}(V)$ (as algebras, these two spaces are of course different). In particular, the dimension of $\operatorname{Cl}(V)$ as a vector space is $2^{n}$ .Also, declaring this basis as being orthonormal, we obtain a scalar product on $\operatorname{Cl}(V)$ extending the one on $V^{'}$ 
We define the degree of $e_{\alpha}$ as being $|\alpha|$ . The $\epsilon_{\alpha}$ of degree $k$ generate the subset $\operatorname{Cl}^{k}(V)$ of elements of degree $k$ Wehave 
$$
\begin{array}{l}{\mathrm{Cl^{0}}=\mathbb{R}}\ {\mathrm{Cl^{1}}=V.}\end{array}
$$
Finally, we let $\mathrm{Cl}^{e v}(V)$ and $\mathrm{Cl}^{o d d}(V)$ be the subspaces of elements of even, resp. odd degree. The former is a subalgebra of $\operatorname{Cl}(V)$ ,butnot thelatter. 
Lemma 1.8.1 The center of $\operatorname{Cl}(V)$ consists of those elements that commute withall $v\in\mathrm{Cl}^{1}(V)=V$ .For $n$ even, the center is $\operatorname{Cl}^{0}(V)$ ,while for n odd, it is $\mathrm{Cl}^{0}(V)\oplus\mathrm{Cl}^{n}(V)$ 
Proof. It suffices to consider basis vectors $e_{\alpha}~=~e_{\alpha_{1}}\ldots\ldots e_{\alpha_{k}}$ as above. For $j\not\in\alpha$ ,wehave 
$$
e_{\alpha}e_{j}=(-1)^{|\alpha|}e_{j}e_{\alpha},
$$
and thus $\left|\alpha\right|$ has to be even for $\epsilon_{\alpha}$ to commute with $\epsilon_{j}$ ,while 
$$
e_{\alpha}e_{\alpha_{j}}=(-1)^{|{\alpha}|-1}e_{\alpha_{j}}e_{\alpha},
$$
